Utterance: Good afternoon! It’s great to see you again. How have you been since our last session?
Hi! Well, I’ve been okay, I guess. The cold is still lingering, but I’m managing.
I’m glad to hear you’re managing. You mentioned some anger issues and how you sometimes react to disappointing news. Have you noticed any changes in that area since we last spoke?
Hmm, I think I’ve been more aware of it. Like, I had a situation last week where I didn’t get a job I applied for, and instead of getting angry, I tried to talk myself through it.
That’s a positive step! How did that process feel for you?
It felt a bit freeing, honestly. I told myself that it just wasn’t the right fit, and I’d find something better.
That’s wonderful! It seems like you’re starting to believe in that perspective. Did you find any specific techniques helpful in managing your emotions during that time?
I did some chanting, which helped calm me down. I also took a walk to clear my head.
Excellent! Incorporating mindfulness and physical activity can be very beneficial. How did you feel afterwards?
I felt lighter, I guess. Like, I didn’t carry that weight of disappointment for too long.
That’s great to hear! It sounds like you’re developing healthier coping strategies. Are there any other situations where you’ve applied this approach?
Well, there was a minor incident with my friend. We got into a disagreement about plans, and instead of blowing up, I just took a moment to breathe and express how I felt calmly.
That’s a significant improvement! How did your friend respond to your calmness?
They were surprised at first but appreciated it. We talked it out and ended up laughing about it later.
Wonderful! It seems like you’re building stronger communication skills. Do you feel this is impacting your relationships positively?
Yes! I think it’s making my friendships feel more stable. I used to worry that my anger would push people away.
That’s a valid concern. It’s great to see you making progress. Are there any areas where you still feel challenged?
Well, I still struggle with feeling dependent on others, especially in relationships. I find it hard to let go sometimes.
That’s understandable. Dependency can be a complex issue. What do you think makes it difficult for you to let go?
I guess it’s fear of being alone. I’ve always had people around me, and the thought of being on my own is scary.
That fear is quite common. It’s important to acknowledge it. Have you considered exploring what being alone could look like for you?
I haven’t really thought about it. It’s more about the feeling of emptiness, I think.
That’s a valuable insight. Perhaps we can work on reframing your thoughts about solitude. It could be an opportunity for self-discovery and growth.
That sounds interesting. I’ve never really looked at it that way.
Let’s try to envision some positive aspects of solitude. What activities or interests do you think you could explore on your own?
I could try painting or writing. I used to enjoy those things before life got busy.
Those are wonderful creative outlets! How would it feel to set aside some time each week for these activities?
It would feel nice, I think. Like I’d be reconnecting with a part of myself I’ve neglected.
Exactly! Reconnecting with yourself can help lessen the fear of being alone. It’s about finding joy in your own company.
I like that idea. I’ll try to dedicate some time for that.
Great! Let’s also touch on your sleep issues. Have you noticed any changes since we last discussed it?
I’m still waking up a lot, especially with this cold. The NyQuil helps, but I know it’s not a long-term solution.
It’s good that you’re aware of that. Have you considered any relaxation techniques before bedtime?
I haven’t really tried anything specific. Just watching TV until I fall asleep.
Watching TV can be stimulating. What if you tried some gentle stretching or meditation before bed?
That sounds like a good idea. I’ve heard meditation can help with sleep.
Absolutely! It can calm the mind and prepare your body for rest. Would you like to try a short guided meditation together now?
Sure, I’d like that!
Alright, let’s take a moment to close our eyes and take a few deep breaths together. Inhale deeply... and exhale slowly...
